title: 109_hr5933
content: The "Business Travel Facilitation Act of 2006" may be cited as the Business Travel Facilitation Act. This Act pertains to business facilitation visitors. Section 214 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include a new category of visitors, business facilitation visitors, who are aliens visiting the US temporarily to provide services. Business facilitation visitors are aliens visiting the US temporarily to provide services or receive management or technical training from a US entity. No alien may be admitted without meeting specific conditions. Business facilitation visitors are aliens who visit the US temporarily to provide services or receive management or technical training from a US entity. No alien may be admitted without meeting specific conditions, including being a national of a country certified by the Secretary of Homeland Security. No alien may be admitted as a business facilitation visitor unless they are a national of a country certified by the Secretary of Homeland Security to combat visa fraud through measures like machine-readable passports and biometric technology. The United States collaborates with other countries to prevent visa fraud by implementing measures like machine-readable passports and biometric technology. Consular officers must verify that the specified conditions are met before issuing a visa under section 101(a)(15)(B). The consular officer must verify that the conditions for provision of services have been met before issuing a visa under section 101(a)(15)(B). Before issuing a visa under section 101(a)(15)(B), the consular officer must verify that the conditions for provision of services have been met, including that all remuneration and expenses related to the services will be paid by the employer and the alien is qualified to provide the services. The alien's employer will pay for expenses related to providing services, and the alien must be qualified with expert knowledge and necessary licenses. The alien must have expert knowledge and required licenses to provide services in the United States. The alien must have expert knowledge and required licenses to provide services in the United States, with conditions related to management or technical training. The alien must have expert knowledge and required licenses to provide services in the United States, with conditions related to management or technical training. The alien must be affiliated with a firm, corporation, or legal entity that is connected to a United States entity through ownership, joint venture, or potential goods purchase. The alien must have expert knowledge and required licenses to provide services in the United States, with conditions related to management or technical training. The alien must be affiliated with a firm, corporation, or legal entity that is connected to a United States entity through ownership, joint venture, or potential goods purchase. The training can be related to purchasing goods or services from, or selling goods or services to, the United States entity. The alien must have expert knowledge and required licenses to provide services in the United States, with conditions related to management or technical training. The training can be related to purchasing goods or services from, or selling goods or services to, the United States entity. Remuneration and expenses for the training will be covered by the alien's employer. The alien's employer will cover all remuneration and expenses for training. The alien must have at least 5 years of management experience and detailed knowledge of business operations. The alien must have at least 5 years of management experience and detailed knowledge of business operations to receive management training. The alien should also hold a management level position within their employer within 1 year of completing the training. The alien seeking management training must have 5 years of management experience and business operations knowledge. They should hold a management level position within their employer within 1 year of completing the training. The period of authorized admission for an alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor providing professional services shall not exceed 1 year, with a possible 6-month extension granted by the Secretary of Homeland Security based on evidence provided by the alien. The Secretary of Homeland Security may grant an alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor providing professional services a single extension of up to 6 months in addition to the initial 1-year period, based on evidence of unforeseen delays in completing the services. The Secretary of Homeland Security may grant an alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor a single extension of up to 6 months due to unforeseen delays in completing services described in the contract. Replacing the alien with another provider would further delay fulfillment of the contract terms. The period of authorized admission for an alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor providing or receiving management or technical training may not exceed 1 year. An alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor shall not be eligible for a change of status. The period of authorized admission for a business facilitation visitor providing or receiving management or technical training is limited to 1 year. Business facilitation visitors are not eligible for a change of nonimmigrant status or adjustment to immigrant status during their stay in the United States. If fraud involving visa is detected among nationals of a country, the Secretary of Homeland Security may authorize countermeasures. The Secretary of Homeland Security may prohibit nationals from admission to the United States as business facilitation visitors if fraud involving visa applications is detected. The Secretary of Homeland Security may prohibit nationals from admission to the United States as business facilitation visitors for a specified period if visa application fraud is detected. A qualifying services contract is defined as a contract between a foreign provider of professional services and a U.S. entity, outlining the time period and duties of the alien in the U.S. The terms of a qualifying services contract between a foreign provider and a U.S. entity include the time period for the alien to be in the U.S., duties to be performed, and provisions for remuneration and expenses. The terms of a qualifying services contract between a foreign provider and a U.S. entity include provisions for the alien's remuneration, expenses, and working conditions comparable to those of similarly situated providers. The alien must have working conditions comparable to those of similar providers of professional services, possess necessary credentials, licenses, and authorizations to work in the United States. The alien must have the necessary credentials and authorizations to work in the United States, including compliance with admission terms. The foreign provider is responsible for ensuring the alien's compliance with admission terms and their return to their home country at the end of their admission period in the United States.
